content.description: This is a definite highball! Follow the sweet rail to the top with a few crimps mixed in.
content.protection: It probably 3 pads plus a spotter to keep you from falling down the mountain over lots of rocks.
content.location: This is on the back side of the huge, balancing boulder (the face that faces downhill). It is to the right of the bolted line.

content.description: Start on the flake down low. DO NOT pull the lower right corner out or you will destroy this problem! The top out is not too bad on the slopers.
content.location: It is about 15 yards from the parking lot.

content.description: Start with a low right hand and crimping with the left. This is easier for the long armed.
content.location:
It is to the right of

V9

.

content.description: Start with your right hand on the arete and your left hand on the small crimp in the middle of the lower face. The crux is moving your left hand from the starting crimp to the next thin crimp on the face.
content.protection: One or two pads - it has a good landing.
content.location:
It is directly to the right of

V1

.

content.description:
Start with your left hand on a crimp in the top of the crack and your right hand on the small crimp-cling out right. Go up to the crimp and then the jug up right. Top out. This is only a 4 move problem but worth doing if you're in this area.

I did this problem only, because it looked like a V4/V5 at the beginning, but it turned out to be super easy (hence the Italian name). Hint... right toe hook the start and go up to the crimp with your right hand not your left, match, then fire for the jug.
content.location: Walk up hill in between the 2 large boulder and veer right for about 20 yards. You'll see it on your left.

content.description: Get a high right hand, and use the break in the center of the boulder paired with jugs on the arete.
content.location: This is on the first big boulder northwest of the parking area. The problem is west-facing.
